column10: In Daigle v. Liberty Life Insurance, the plaintiff, Ray Daigle, appealed the district court's judgment in his discrimination suit against his former employer, Liberty Life Insurance Company. Daigle claimed that Liberty discriminated against him based on his learning disability in violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA). Liberty argued that Daigle was terminated due to his mistreatment of employees and dishonesty. At trial, conflicting evidence was presented regarding both parties' positions. The jury found that Daigle had not proven that his termination was due to a disability or that Liberty's proffered reason for the termination was a pretense for discrimination. Daigle appealed the judgment, arguing that Liberty failed to present any evidence to create a disputed fact issue as to the existence of his disability. The Americans with Disabilities Act prohibits discrimination against a qualified individual with a disability in regard to employment. A plaintiff can establish a claim of disability discrimination by presenting direct evidence or using the McDonnell Douglas analysis, which requires showing that the plaintiff suffers from a disability, is qualified for the job, was subject to an adverse employment action, and was replaced by a non-disabled person or treated less favorably than non-disabled employees. Once the plaintiff has stated a prima facie case, the employer must articulate a legitimate nondiscriminatory reason for its action. Daigle argued that the district court erred in denying his motion for partial summary judgment because Liberty failed to present any evidence to create a disputed fact issue as to the existence of his disability. However, the Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit held that it would focus on the evidence before the jury at trial instead of the evidence before the judge during pretrial activities. After reviewing the evidence, the Court affirmed the district court's judgment. Major statute law applied: Americans with Disabilities Act (42 U.S.C. § 12112(a) and 42 U.S.C. § 12111(8)).

column5: In Perez-Sosa v. Garland, the plaintiff, a former federal attorney, challenged the district court's fee award of $170,331.56 in attorneys' fees, arguing that it did not reasonably compensate his attorney for her time. The case arose from a Title VII employment discrimination dispute, and the plaintiff's attorney had spent over 1,200 hours on the case. The district court used the lodestar method to calculate the fee award, setting Attorney Almodóvar's hourly rate at $275 for core legal work and $165 for non-core work. The plaintiff challenged several rulings made by the district court in constructing the fee award, including the exclusion of time spent on settlement negotiations and time spent on work connected to other cases. The First Circuit held that the district court erred in categorically excluding time spent on settlement negotiations from the lodestar calculation. The court reasoned that settlement negotiations are an essential part of civil rights cases and should be compensable as long as they are reasonable and productive. The court also held that the district court erred in excluding time spent on work connected to other cases if that work was useful and of a type ordinarily necessary to secure the final result obtained from the litigation. The court remanded the case for further proceedings, allowing credit for all time reasonably spent by the plaintiff's counsel during the course of settlement negotiations and in performing useful and ordinarily necessary work in connection with other cases. Major statute law applied: Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (42 U.S.C. § 2000e et seq.) and the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission regulations (29 C.F.R. § 16b).

Salt Lake County , the Tenth Circuit held that a prevailing Title VII plaintiff may not recover attorneys' fees for time spent in navigating the employer's optional grievance process even if such work was “useful and of a type ordinarily necessary to secure the final result obtained from the litigation.” 754 F.3d 864, 870 (10th Cir. 2014) (internal quotations omitted) (quoting Pennsylvania v. Del. Valley Citizens' Council for Clean Air (Delaware Valley ), 478 U.S. 546, 561, 106 S.Ct. 3088, 92 L.Ed.2d 439 (1986)). There, the court decided that the useful-and-necessary standard does not apply to actions under Title VII. See id. at 870-71; cf. Binta B. ex rel. S.A. v. Gordon, 710 F.3d 608, 631 (6th Cir. 2013) (“[W]e are troubled by the idea of ever permitting plaintiffs' counsel to receive fees for work performed in a completely separate case.”).

We do not agree. To determine “the number of hours reasonably expended on the litigation,” Hensley, 461 U.S. at 433, 103 S.Ct. 1933, an inquiring court must look not to labels but, rather, to the nature of the work and its utility to the case at hand, see Delaware Valley, 478 U.S. at 561, 106 S.Ct. 3088. That “look” is not constrained by the four corners of the particular case. See Nat'l Ass'n of Concerned Veterans v. Sec'y of Def., 675 F.2d 1319, 1335 (D.C. Cir. 1982). Instead, a court should award fees for all hours logged in connection with work that is “‘useful and of a type ordinarily necessary’ to secure the final result obtained from the litigation.” Delaware Valley, 478 U.S. at 561, 106 S.Ct. 3088 (quoting Webb v. Bd. of Educ., 471 U.S. 234, 243, 105 S.Ct. 1923, 85 L.Ed.2d 233 (1985)); see Hutchinson ex rel. Julien v. Patrick, 636 F.3d 1, 15 (1st Cir. 2011). This standard controls even when that work implicates some other case. See Schneider v. Colegio de Abogados de P.R., 187 F.3d 30, 32-33 (1st Cir. 1999) (per curiam) (applying the “useful and of a type ordinarily necessary” standard to “work done in the [Puerto Rico] courts before the filing of the federal lawsuit”).

column5: In the case of Sanchez v. Vilsack, Clarice Sanchez, a long-time Forest Service employee, suffered irreversible brain damage after falling at work, resulting in a permanent vision impairment. Sanchez requested a hardship transfer to Albuquerque, New Mexico, for medical treatment and support from her family and friends. The Forest Service denied her request and Sanchez filed a lawsuit under the Rehabilitation Act, alleging discrimination and a hostile work environment. Sanchez argued that her vision impairment substantially limited her major life activity of seeing and qualified as a disability under the Rehabilitation Act. The Forest Service countered that Sanchez was not substantially limited in her ability to see and that transfer accommodations were not required by the Act. The Tenth Circuit Court of Appeals held that Sanchez had raised a genuine issue of material fact regarding her disability. The court found that Sanchez's vision impairment significantly limited her ability to see as compared to the average person, and that she had presented evidence of the challenges it caused in her daily life. The court also rejected the Forest Service's argument that transfer accommodations were not required by the Rehabilitation Act. The court noted that the Act requires employers to provide reasonable accommodations for disabled employees, including reassignment to a vacant position if the employee is qualified for the job and it does not impose an undue burden on the employer. The court further held that accommodations may be required to allow an employee to pursue therapy or treatment for their disability or to enjoy equal benefits and privileges of employment. Major statute law applied: The Rehabilitation Act of 1973, 29 U.S.C. § 791 et seq., and the Americans with Disabilities Act, 42 U.S.C. § 12101 et seq.
column10: Patricia Woodman, a USPS employee since 1981, filed a disability discrimination action against the USPS under the Vocational Rehabilitation Act of 1973 and Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. The USPS had assigned Woodman to various jobs due to her injuries, but she contended that these assignments did not meet her medical restrictions and constituted discrimination. The district court granted the USPS's motion for summary judgment, and Woodman appealed. Woodman argued that she is a qualified individual with a disability, that the USPS failed to reasonably accommodate her disability by providing her with a permanent job assignment within her medical limitations, and that such failure constituted discrimination on the basis of disability. The USPS argued that Woodman was not a qualified individual due to her inability to perform the essential functions of her previous job, and that it had no duty to reassign her to a permanent position as there was no funded vacant position available within her craft, work facility, and work hours consistent with her medical restrictions. The court held that there were genuine issues of material fact precluding judgment as a matter of law. Woodman had provided evidence that she could be reasonably accommodated with a permanent assignment to consumer affairs, and the USPS had not shown that such reassignment would be inconsistent with the terms of the collective bargaining agreement. The court also noted that the USPS had a duty to investigate the possibility of permanent reassignment and had not met this obligation. Major statute law applied: The Vocational Rehabilitation Act of 1973, 29 U.S.C. §§ 791 and 794, and Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, 42 U.S.C. §§ 2000 et seq.

column10: In Mark Bledsoe v. Palm Beach County Soil and Water Conservation District, the plaintiff, Bledsoe, a former Resource Technician for the District, alleged that he was terminated due to his disability in violation of Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Rehabilitation Act. The District argued that it was not Bledsoe's employer and that the partial release in his workers' compensation settlement barred his federal claims of employment discrimination. The court held that the workers' compensation release did not bar Bledsoe's federal claims, as the release language did not mention a waiver of federal discrimination claims and there was no evidence of consideration given in exchange for the waiver. The court also determined that Title II of the ADA encompasses employment discrimination, as evidenced by the statutory language, DOJ regulations, and the court's own previous decisions. Major statute law applied: Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act (42 U.S.C. § 12131 et seq.) and the Rehabilitation Act (29 U.S.C. § 701, et seq.).

We are mindful that most courts have held that Title II applies to employment. Ordinarily, we would find it difficult to hold that the wording of a statute unambiguously indicates a contrary congressional intent in the face of such precedent. However, those courts generally have ignored the wording of Title II altogether,[fn11] including the definition of "qualified individual with a disability" from that Title and the surrounding words in 42 U.S.C. § 12132. Instead, they have: (1) assumed without analysis that Title II applies to employment,[fn12] (2) relied only on the Attorney General's regulation and the legislative history of the ADA, without discussion of the statutory text and context,[fn13] (3) relied on the Rehabilitation Act without analyzing whether Congress intended to incorporate its prohibition against employment discrimination
into Title II,[fn14] or (4) relied solely on the foregoing precedent without independent consideration of the problem.[fn15] Because of the limited analysis performed in those cases —
in particular, their failure to consider the statutory text and context carefully — we simply do not find them persuasive.

column10: In John Doe v. University of Maryland Medical System Corporation, Dr. Doe, an HIV-positive neurosurgical resident, brought a lawsuit against UMMSC for discrimination under § 504 of the Rehabilitation Act and Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA). UMMSC terminated Dr. Doe's residency due to the risk of HIV transmission during exposure-prone procedures. The district court granted summary judgment to UMMSC, and Dr. Doe appealed. Dr. Doe argued that he was an otherwise qualified individual with a disability under both statutes, as he was qualified for the residency before his HIV diagnosis and was not a significant risk to the health or safety of patients that could not be eliminated by reasonable accommodation. UMMSC countered that HIV poses a significant risk due to its transmissibility via blood-to-blood contact, the fact that Dr. Doe will always be infectious, and the potential severity of harm to third parties. The court applied the Arline test, which considers the nature, duration, severity, and probabilities of the risk. The court held that Dr. Doe did pose a significant risk due to the types of procedures he was engaged in as a neurosurgical resident and the impossibility of eliminating the risk of percutaneous injury through reasonable accommodation. Dr. Doe also argued that UMMSC's differential treatment of HIV-positive HCWs based on whether their status was known violated the Equal Protection Clause. However, the court held that this classification was rationally related to the legitimate interest of protecting the health of patients. Major statute law applied: § 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (29 U.S.C.A. § 794) and Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act (42 U.S.C.A. § 12132).

column7: Alberti v. City & County of San Francisco Sheriff's Department
column10: In Alberti v. City & County of San Francisco Sheriff's Department, the plaintiff, Robert Alberti, a person with learning disabilities, brought an Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) action against the defendants for employment discrimination and harassment. Alberti argued that Title II of the ADA covers employment discrimination, while defendants contended that it does not and that Alberti failed to exhaust administrative remedies for his Title I and Title II claims. The court began by examining whether Title II covers employment discrimination. Alberti argued that Title II's broad language, which prohibits discrimination "by any such entity," includes employment discrimination. Defendants countered that the absence of the word "employment" in the statute indicates that it does not apply to employment discrimination. The court found that Title II's legislative history and the Department of Justice's interpretation support Alberti's argument. Regarding the timeliness of Alberti's claims, the court held that a one-year statute of limitations applies to Title II claims based on California personal injury law. Alberti filed his Title II complaint with the Department of Justice (DOJ) within one year of the alleged discrimination but did not receive a right-to-sue letter until after the two-year delay in the DOJ's handling of his complaint. The court applied the doctrine of equitable tolling and found that Alberti met the three-prong test for invoking equitable tolling. The court granted defendants' motion to dismiss Alberti's Title I claims for failure to exhaust administrative remedies. However, it granted Alberti leave to amend his Title II complaint to allege equitable tolling. The court dismissed Alberti's FEHA claims due to his failure to exhaust administrative remedies, as the jurisdictional requirement of exhaustion is not waivable. Major statute law applied: Title I and Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act (42 U.S.C. § 12101 et seq.) and the California Fair Employment and Housing Act (Cal. column5: Plaintiff, Scot L. Zimmerman, brought an action against the State of Oregon Department of Justice (Defendant) claiming discrimination in employment in violation of Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and a similar state anti-discrimination statute. The district court dismissed the Title II claim, holding that it does not apply to employment. On appeal, Plaintiff argues that the court erred in this interpretation. The Ninth Circuit, affirming, held that Title II does not apply to employment based on the statutory text and context, as well as the structure of the ADA as a whole. Key arguments of the parties: Plaintiff argued that Title II's broad language and the Attorney General's regulation under Chevron deference should apply to employment discrimination. Defendant argued that the plain language of Title II and the structure of the ADA demonstrate that Congress did not intend for Title II to apply to employment. Court's conclusion: The Ninth Circuit held that Title II does not apply to employment based on the statutory text and context, as well as the structure of the ADA as a whole. Major statute law being applied: 1. Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), Title II, 42 U.S.C. § 12131 et seq. 2. Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, as amended, 42 U.S.C. § 2000e et seq. 3. The Rehabilitation Act, 29 U.S.C. § 701 et seq.

column10: In Downs v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority, Downs, a job applicant, sued his former employer, the MBTA, for wrongful termination after being fired following the discovery of false answers he had given during a pre-employment medical examination. Downs argued that the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Rehabilitation Act prohibited the MBTA from asking questions regarding his prior workers' compensation claims and disability status, and that the MBTA violated confidentiality requirements imposed by these statutes. The MBTA moved for summary judgment, arguing that Title II of the ADA and Title I of the ADA did not apply to employment discrimination claims, and that Downs failed to file a timely charge of discrimination with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC). Downs replied to an MBTA advertisement in 1989 and underwent a two-part preliminary screening process, including a driver's test and a personality inventory. After passing these examinations, he was invited for a physical examination and a conditional offer of employment. During the medical examination, Downs answered negatively to questions regarding his workers' compensation history and joint pains, despite having received workers' compensation for elbow injuries in the past. The MBTA discovered these false answers when evaluating a later workers' compensation claim and terminated Downs for falsifying information on his employment application. The court held that Title II of the ADA applies to employment discrimination claims and that the MBTA's arguments regarding the procedural requirements of Title I and the timeliness of Downs's EEOC charge were without merit. The court also rejected the MBTA's contention that Downs's false answers to medical inquiries prevented him from pursuing his claims, as the MBTA had violated the ADA and Rehabilitation Act by asking impermissible questions during the pre-employment medical examination. Major statute law applied: Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act (42 U.S.C. § 12131 et seq.) and Title I of the Americans with Disabilities Act (42 U.S.C. § 12111 et seq.) and the Rehabilitation Act (29 U.S.C. § 794).
